invitation: ^: Standing before an impressive manor, you quickly check the invitaion you received a fortnight prior, disbelieving your good fortnue.
^: "The Marquess and Marchioness of Derby request the pleasure of Miss Ruth Leigh's company at dinner on Thursday, the 14th of April, at 5 o’clock."
^: Along with the decadent note came a glorious gown and heels, which you now don. You are not used to such elaborate garments and buckle under the weight of the many layers.
^: Attached to the dress was a short note, in a script dissimilar to what appeared on the invitation
^"Surely, my dear Ruth, you have nothing to wear?"

s: ^You were disarmed by hostile familarity of the note,
c: ^but the chance to mingle with the likes of high society were too promising to miss.
^but the chance to mingle with the likes of high society were too promising to miss.
^and were overjoyed that some guardian had placed you in good hands.

excite: ^With anxious exitcement, you stare expecetedly at Rose House, wondering what the evening holds for you.

s1: ^ After occupying ourself for a short while, you arrived
s2: ^Surely, you figure, it is time to enter
s3: ^ If fifteen minutes is fashionably late, then I must be excelling in style at

s1: ^at Rose House again at exactly five o'clock.

s0: ^and take a stroll around the block. A street barker shouts the news of the day and you intently listen.
s1: ^ and hoped to find something of interest on the street. You glance at your heels, wishing you had a more comfortable option.
s2: ^, and feel as if you will truly make quite an entrance.

introductions: ^: A manservant stands before you and looks approvingly at your dress.
^:You hand him your invitation and, without a word, he escorts you down a series of hallways, ending in a densely decorated parlor room.
^: A woman of a certain age walks briskly towards you with a perplexed look on her face.
^Marchioness of Derby: Hello, my dear. I do not believe I've looked upon your face before. I imagine you are here for my intimatie soiree considering my footman let you through.
^Marchioness of Derby: You have the pleasure of my acquaintance, the Marchioness of Derby. I assume you must have heard of me, but again, I have not heard of you.

c: ^and the Marchioness lets out a small scoff in return.
^Marchioness of Derby: Well, I could never imagine a commoner would grace the halls of Rose House, but I suppose you were invited. An oversight on someone's part, surely.
^Marchioness of Derby: Regardless, please let me show you the other guests. They are quite distinguished, unlike youself.
^Marchioness of Derby: How wonderful! I suppose your father is quite a remarkable gentleman. I must thank whomever invited such a delightful creature.
^Marchioness of Derby: Please, let me show you to the other guests. They are quite distinguished, like yourself.
^Marchioness of Derby: Superb! Dreadful business about your late husband, I gather, but I must thank whomever invited such a distinguished guest.
^Marchioness of Derby: It is not every day we have such a honor to grace Rose House. Please, let me show you to the other guest, though I imagine you are more familiar with greater company.

b: ^Marchioness of Derby: By the by, I cannot abide by a lack of etiquette. Whoever you are, you must not arrive at Rose House at such an inopportune time.

^Marchioness of Derby: By the by, I approve of your adherence to proper etiquette. It is of the upmost importance in my home. If only all our guests matched your elegance and arrived at the Rose House at the proper time.

time: ^: You are finally given a chance to properly survey the room. A number of guests are talking idly throughout. They seem to be waiting expectantly to be called to dinner.
^: Several of the men immediately draw your attention. They give the apperance of eligible bachelors, eyeing up the female guests for suitable qualities.
^: A woman, about your age, gives you a queer look you cannot place as you glance around.

introduce_self: ^or at least you start to, but before you can finish the Marchioness interupts.
^Marchioness of Derby: No, no my dear. You must know the gentleman always introduce themselves first.
bachelor_And_Camilla_Intro: ^: The Marchioness waves a hand at each of the men in turn.
^Lord Essex: You may address me as Lord Essex, if you find it suitable. I await the pleasure of your acquaintance.
^: Lord Essex appears a proper gentleman, if not a tad stiff. Perhaps the right mate could warm his cold heart.
^Lord Ascot: Good evening, or, as they say in great Nippon, konbanwa! I am called Lord Ascot, and not just due to my dashing attire.
^: Lord Ascot looks to be an eccentric but clearly a friendly one at that. You sense that he is often the life of the party and is looking for someone who can keep up.

^Lord Bath: My lady, your beauty is as radiant as a young moon. I am eager to meet our "golden close of love" as my dear friend Alfred once said. The gentry label me as Lord Bath, but you may call me as you please.
^: Lord Bath might need to follow his name-sake as his disheleved apperance seems at odds with the occasion. Still you note his easy flirtation.
^: The Marchioness then turns to the queer-looking woman and remarks.
^Marchioness of Derby: And finally, this is my dearest daughter, Lady Camilla.
^Lady Camilla: Lady Camilla gives you the same look and a slight smile.
^: The Marchioness looks to you and says
^. Feel free to mingle, my dear. Dinner will be served shortly.

b: ^: I am pleased you respect my stature. Too many place familiarity above formality these days.
^: You do me the honor of such an adresss but no doubt there is no need to demean yourself.

c: ^: Did you just address me -- aha, I get it. You must be joking with such needless formality. Yes yes, very clever.

b: ^: Why, such forthrightness is rare these days. I am impressed with your command of your superior station.
^: Why, I never have been so insulted by one so common.

g-0: ^: Did you come over to chat with me?

c: ^Now now, no need to steer polite conversation into such clefted water. It wouldn't be prudent.
^Yes, a most pleasant topic. This long bout of overcast weather we've been having has suited me well this Spring.
^I say! You should know a gentleman only speaks of financial affairs with his closest confidants and his wife. Do you already presume to be as such? Harumph!
^: No need for such formality. If I wanted to talk to a marm I would dine at a schoolhouse. Totemo vulgar.
^: Omoshiroi! What a fabulous witticism. I sense a strong sense of irony in you.
^: Sugoi! Not everyone gets the line, but you caught on quick. I have quite the collection as you may have guessed.

g-0: ^: Well, my good miss, what do you like to do for leisure?

c: ^Ugh. I understand being prodigal, but spending all that money just to shoot an innocent creature? Poor little kitsunes.
^A common enough interest, if a little dull for my tastes. At least the horses all have colorful names, I suppose.
^A sense of humor? Subarashi! My peers say Punch is a middle-class rag, but they wouldn't know satire if it yanked their tailcoats.
^: Dearest, my love, I scoff at wealth. As my friend William says
^: "Is this a holy thing to see
^: In a rich and fruitful land,
^: Fed with cold and usurous hand?"
^: Although my dearest friend, Byron, has said:
^"Money, that most pure imagination, gleams only through the dawn of its creation."
^Do not mistake me for a patrician. I shirk such titles.
^: Ah, so informal already? No matter, I welcome the intimacy.
^: My friend William once wrote of seeing Heaven in a wild flower, but I can only imagine what he would have seen in one as comely as you.

g-0: ^: You know, you're the right age to have marriage on your mind, and you strike me as someone pining for courtship. What kind of wedding do you want?

s: ^A big wedding in a fashionable church

c: ^: A scandalous streak in you, eh? You know, many of my friends have eloped to Gretna Green. They say the blacksmith acts as witness.
^: I suppose your preference in romance is more Dickens and less Dante.
^: It appears you have at least some training in how to address your betters.
^: That is my mother's name. You must be disoriented, or perhaps just out of place.
^: Remember who you speak to, Miss Leigh. Even commoners must observe basic decorum.

g-0: ^: Hello, Miss Leigh. You must be wondering why someone of your low station received an invitation to an event as luxurious as my mother's party.

^: Well, I'm the one who sent it! I saw you walking down Regent Street and knew you'd be perfect for my needs. The way you walked and dressed... why, it looked as though you just didn't care what anyone thought of you!
^ is looking at you eagerly for a response.

s: ^What a marvelous dress you’re wearing, it really slims your figure.
^You want a punch in the sauce-box, church-bell?

g-1: ^: Listen here, you little strumpet. The only reason you’re at this party is to make me look good by comparison.
^: Do you think your peasant manners will let you fit in with a crowd of aristocrats? Ohoho! Your indelicacy is going to help me find a husband tonight!

march_Order: ^Marchioness of Derby: Pardon me, but I just remembered that you don't have an escort for dinner, dear! If you would please just answer a few questions, I can match you with an appropriate gentleman.

c: ^Marchioness of Derby: He must be a respectable man.
^Marchioness of Derby: Really? You know, I’ve heard the Queen visits Nice often.
^Marchioness of Derby: The seaside? How quaint…
^Marchioness of Derby: How fashionable of you!
^Marchioness of Derby: Like a proper young lady should.
^Marchioness of Derby: Oh, dear. An unfortunate family tradition, I hope.

dinner: ^You are seated at a table with

table_manners: ^A footman places a shallow bowl of pea soup in front of you. Do you..

c: ^You receive narrowed eyes and throat clearings from the diners around you, except for the Viscount Ascot.
^When he sees you dip your bread into the pea soup, he chuckles, then mimes doing it himself.

s: ^Eat it with a spoon, sipping from the side
^Eat it with a spoon, blowing on it and sipping from the tip

g-0: ^The footman takes the bowl of pea soup away, and replaces it with a steaming plate of trout. You eat it with...

s: ^Knife in right hand, fork in left
^Napkin in right hand, fork in left
^Fork in right hand, bread in left

g-1: ^The footman takes the main course away, and places in front of you a small plate of the most Victorian of desserts, sponge pudding. Do you...

c: ^The table is aghast at your barbarous consumption of the pudding, except for the Marquess Bath.
^His eyes are ablaze with lust after witnessing your passionate eating style.

conversation_dinner: ^There is a lull in the conversation

dinner_rando: ^: The nameless gentleman had nothing of import to sa.
^: This dinner is excellent. You looked as though you were especially enjoying your soup.

s: ^It was so tasty I thought about asking for seconds
c: ^: Well, good that you didn't. It's most unbecoming to ask for second helpings of soup, unless it's chowder of course.

dinner_Ascot: ^: I just returned from a trip to Yokohama. You really must go, it's so delightfully rustic! Do you have any interest in the Far East?

s: ^I've heard China is a beautiful country
c: ^: Really? From the photographs I've seen China looks as though its best days are well behind it. It cannot compare to how kirei Nippon is.
^: Yes, the Chinese do make some dazzling porcelain. A shame that country itself is stuck in the past, so the people are backwards.
^: Unlike Nippon! The people there are so noble, like they’re living in the days of yore.
